questions.promptMd: Which evidence combo BEST signals ethos holistically?
questions.rationaleMd: Weighs proof of expertise, reliability, and benevolence together.

answers.contentMd: Two case studies (metrics) + on‑time delivery record + option favorable to counterparty’s constraint
answers.feedbackMd: Covers expertise, reliability, and benevolence concretely.
Claims without proof; tone is not evidence.

answers.contentMd: Anecdote from a friend + urgent deadline
answers.feedbackMd: Weak proof and pressure reduce trust.

answers.contentMd: Generic logo slide + big future promises
answers.feedbackMd: Logos without outcomes and vague promises are weak.

questions.promptMd: True or False: Benevolence is better shown by trading value to the other side than by asserting "we care".

answers.feedbackMd: Correct. Concrete trades and concessions signal aligned intent.

questions.promptMd: Which behavior MOST undermines perceived reliability?

answers.contentMd: Irregular updates that force stakeholders to chase for status
Acknowledging a miss with a remedy plan
answers.feedbackMd: Can strengthen trust if done well.

questions.promptMd: True or False: Stating credentials at length is superior to linking concise, verifiable outcomes.

answers.feedbackMd: Outcome‑based proof is more persuasive and efficient.
Correct. Briefly state credentials; lead with outcomes and evidence.
